displayed_text: Family Member: So they’ll approve it probably the next Thursday? Doctor: Correct. Exactly. And then they’ll say oh the note says you’re off study this is standard run of the mill dose of taxo… oh you want to give Neulasta on day two because you’re worried about having compromise of your white cells, which is still a little you know not at the most robust, but your cell lines have- Patient: Sure. Doctor: - gone down because of the previous chemo. But look we have a great respond, so let’s just move on boys and girls. Doctor: And the then they’ll go oh that makes sense Stan and then you show up and then there we are. Patient: Yeah, okay, okay. Doctor: So I think we should just reschedule for next Thursday, the shot on Friday and that’s that. Patient: Okay, okay. Reschedule what for next Thursday? Family Member: Chemo. Doctor: Chemo. Patient: Oh and then have that follow-up shot on Friday? Doctor: Correct.

Patient: As needed. Doctor: The Lisinopril twenty milligrams day? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Metoprolol a hundred milligrams a day. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Mometasone or Nasonex sprays. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Oxycodone immediate release five milligrams. Patient: No, that’s been set up for ten milligrams, and that’s as needed now after it’s been about two weeks since my radiation. Doctor: So it’s that ten milligram pill you take? Patient: No it’s two fives. Doctor: Oh, yeah. The OxyContin? And the OxyContin is thirty milligrams twice a day? Patient: Once a day; I’m taking it once a day now.

Family Member: You don't know yet if you want to do the trial. Patient: If I do the trial. I take what they give me. Family Member: Oh, that's right. Doctor: Yeah there's no choice there. Family Member: So if he wants to go somewhere, what’s the longest period of time he can be gone? Doctor: Oh. Well, probably three or four weeks Family Member: You can handle that. Doctor: Yeah, there is like a you know, plus minus, so if it’s like a special thing you know, might be five or six weeks so we can work with you guys. Because people have lives and they take vacation, they have other things they gotta do. Family Member: Right Doctor: That isn’t just cancer. Family Member: Actually I thought it was going to be worse, but you’re saying it’s every three weeks or so. I’m pretty surprised. I’m surprised. Doctor: Yeah, for standard dosing, just no trial, just once for an hour every three weeks is the infusion. Of course you know, I K_____ world that's a half a day, but still, it's not you know, every day you have to be here or anything like that.

Patient: I need my OxyContin. Doctor: Yeah the OxyContin you’re gonna get no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That you keep going. Patient: Okay. Take Percocet… Doctor: Instead of the Norco. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Right. Healthcare Professional: Alright. Doctor: So let’s do that, see how you do and then we’ll switch, we’ll add the sleeping pill. Patient: Okay.

Patient: I did. Doctor: Yeah, so it’s- Patient: Yeah, I, I, when they, they said I had phlebotomy, I asked if it was fasting, and they said “No.” So, I, uh, ate breakfast. Doctor: And your PSA today is twenty-two. Patient: Ouch. Doctor: That’s all good. And your testosterone is (pause6sec) Patient: Okay. Question. Sixteen to seventeen, and I don’t know the time frame that it went from sixteen to seventeen, but in (cell phone rings) Doctor: Yeah, don’t read much into it. You know, we’re just checking it more often. Patient: Well, I understand that, but what does that mean to the aggressiveness of the cancer? Does it - Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I mean my sense is that people who, let’s - I don’t have prostate cancer that I know of right now - but, if my PSA was going up and I don’t have the diagnosis, it sort of tells me if it’s going up that fast that I’m more likely when I put a needle in it to find bad cancer. So, we already know you’ve got bad cancer. Patient: Yeah. So, this is, doesn’t tell you. Doctor: Doesn’t tell you. Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck?

Patient: Okay. Alright. Family Member: If he has non-cancer issues, he goes to him primary? Patient: Primary doctor, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, they’re smarter than us. Family Member: If he thinks he has a hernia, would that show on the CT scan? Would that be appropriate to send to the doctor? Doctor: No, because, yeah, the hernia, you know, when you’re laying down it really has to be pretty bad for it to be seen laying down. It’s usually when you’re standing up or sitting that it comes out. A hernia just means you have a weak area of muscle and then you have your bowel spill out. Typically, it doesn’t bother you unless it gets stuck, you know. Patient: Okay. Family Member: He’s having a lot of pain shooting up. Patient: Just I have a problem with my groin Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Uh don’t wait you know for having, having sex with somebody, Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: take it so that uh, it’s like medication you would take on a regular basis… Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Take that so that it keeps the blood flow going. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And with time, like more months, like up to September. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: In September if that that – if nothing happens, then we can go to another ah step Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: in treating the sexual function.

Patient: Okay. Okay. That works. Doctor: Questions? Family Member: I do, I think that, uh, one of the, I guess, questions that came up in my mind was the signs of the cancer development in the adrenal is it consistent that it would be prostate cancer or we just don’t even know Doctor: Yeah. I mean, the assumption is that it is prostate cancer. Why give him a second cancer? Uh. So, that’s the assumption. You know, the adrenal gland can have benign tumors in it. Okay? Um. You know, if prostate cancer went in there, that would be a possible reason why it would bleed. Um. Sometimes the adrenal gland just doesn’t get a good blood supply, and it does bleed. Or, if you’re under stress, or like today with your blood pressure shooting through the roof, but your scans were yesterday. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh. It’s pretty nonspecific. Your aspirin puts you at a higher risk for like various Doctor: -things, such as bleeding. Patient: Okay. Should I stop that? Doctor: No. I mean, my sense is you’ve been on it for some reason. I, but, we didn’t start it, right? Patient: Yeah, yeah. My, um, primary doctor did. Doctor: So, you know, that would be the person to check. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you. Doctor: Yes. I agree with you. Patient: And I also had a question about that proton treatment that they have in B___. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Um Doctor: Not ah truly applicable to you at this point. That’s great for if you were just newly diagnosed with your prostate cancer or if you have some specific area on your spine. You obviously just got the radiation to there but if you know you’re a baby, for example, and you had a really tiny spinal cord, and you have this cancer next to it, a proton would be the perfect treatment. For adults, it’s a little harder to know what is better than the standard. So you know you hope maybe if you got protons you wouldn’t have had so many side effects. That’s possible. But it’s not as mainstream I think as we’d like to see it. At some point now when they’re really up and running and more patients will get experience, we’ll probably get a better sense of that. But for now I think you’ve got the best treatment which was those three areas in the spine and then your pelvis. Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-? Doctor: It’s supposed to be but I think the question is you know for the extra twenty or thirty thousand dollars that it costs- Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: -is that truly better than what the regulation radiation is going to afford because it’s not the old time radiation. The radiation you got is still image guided. It’s still blocked off. So those studies are ongoing. And that’s why not every center and not every state has protons. Because the cost is just astronomical- Family Member: Really. Doctor: -and not every insurance company is really paying for it. And you don’t know if it’s better. So this issue comes around a lot because of prostate. So protons wanted to replace, you know, oh, and I going to save the bladder or anything else. And that data doesn’t show it to be better necessarily. So it’s a big fight between the radiation guys. They’re trying to figure that out themselves. Um, but I don’t know. I think it’s good technology. So I think if needed, if it was a really tough spot or really small area I think it’s reasonable. But you had many spots that the radiation had to go after so I’m not sure that much of an advantage would have been gained. Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time-

Family Member: And he’s not walking this time. He has an unsteady gait. He’s stumbling. Doctor: No? Really? Patient: No I ain’t walking the same. Family Member: And I told him he’s a fall risk so I’d like him to take his cane with him. He says well it’s in my truck, but you can fall going from the house to your truck. Doctor: I agree. Better to keep it. Family Member: Period. Doctor: It’s still better than having to use a walker otherwise. So that’s… Family Member: I’m not walking outside with that cane. That’s what you told me last week. And I said alright just go ahead and fall because I’m not coming out to get you. I don’t want to see you hurt that’s why I think preventive measures Doctor: A fracture now would really set us back. So- Family Member: Yes because we have brittle bones. Doctor: And I might put in for a bone strengthening medication just so you know it starts, uh it’s an injection. So if he can get it authorized and all that we might as well start it about every few months we’ll have to do it, so not that often. Family Member: I’m not opposed to that. Anything that will help J___ -

Patient: Merci Beaucoup. Doctor: Hope for the best right? Patient: I’m still recovering from the call and everybody keeps pushing their hand out. Why don’t you do the fist bump? Doctor: Yeah the first bump. Yeah I guess I should get with the times. Patient: I guess the fist bump is less contagious isn’t it? Doctor: Okay now maybe. Yeah you’re right. Although my son has told me that is - Family Member: Out? Doctor: -would be very weird if I did it. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah there are some words that are off limits for me. Patient: It’s medical purposes. Doctor: Yeah exactly. No don’t try to be cool with your kid.

Patient: the mountains the desert everything. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I understand what you’re saying. Doctor: Yeah I can only express my concern. Patient: And I got emergency stops that I can hit it… Doctor: Okay. When are you going? Doctor: You want to wait until we know if this medicine does well or you go first and then we start the medicine? Patient: Ooooh I wanted to go to the F___. Doctor: Okay. Patient: We’re having, my church is having a bike blessing on the twenty fourth. Doctor: Of? Patient: Of this month. Doctor: Oh, okay, fine.

Family Member: Of how I see it going? And then he can correct me if I’m wrong. But I feel like, um, D___ is in pain often, and, um, it’s, I would say the past two weeks, I would say like maybe last week, maybe a week and a half ago, he was in a lot of pain and very weak, from my perspective, what I am seeing. And, um, so often, and often would mean almost nightly, I am rubbing him with either Salonpas or Aspercreme or Bengay, one of the three, on his back, shoulders, legs, so that he can feel comfortable enough so he can lay down and rest. So, you know, that’s how I see it. I don’t know if he feels, if maybe I’m interpreting his pain to be more than it is, but when he asks me to rub, you know, rub something on his back, in my mind it’s pain. When I look at his face, I see that he’s in pain. So that’s what I see. And, you know, it might be that he’s like no, P___, it’s not that bad. On a scale of one to ten, it might be seven, but when I look at him, I’m seeing eight, nine. Doctor: We’ve got a thing to keep in mind is in your case we decided to try this study because of the genetic mutations that your tumor had. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it wasn’t that we tried this study because you had exhausted all other options. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the reason we’re saying that is because there are other things out there that your cancer has a good chance of responding well to. For example, uh, the alternative hormone therapy called Xtandi, that you have not received. You have received the one called, Zytiga. But there’s a similar one that was FDA approved about a year after the Zytiga was approved, called Xtandi. And it’s an oral hormone therapy pill. That medication does not work that well after people have received Zytiga first because it’s similarly related to that drug, but that’s an option. The second option is intravenous chemotherapy, which you have also not received. Um, which I know that you have been reluctant to think about it in the past, but that clearly is an option. So you have a minimum of two FDA-approved options that you have not tried yet. So knowing that, um, from my perspective, like I’m going to be a little less sort of heroic and like waiting to see if this is going to work or not. Because it’s not like you’ve run out of options, and this is the last thing we’re going to try anyway. You know? There are other options out there. Because we do have those options, yes, one of them is a chemo. Um, we also don’t want this cancer to advance too quickly that we miss the window and you get too sick and too frail, you know, to be able to tolerate those other therapies. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that, that is also in the back of my mind. And, because, because then I feel like we might have actually harmed you by missing the opportunity to give, you know, an FDA-approved therapy. Of course, that would be through K___ because that would be standard therapy. Um, so that’s what the other part of my thinking. Patient: Okay. And, and from my perspective, I didn’t believe that this was going to be easy from the, from the beginning. I remember when I came, I came to J___ H___ for a reason. I came here for a consultation because I wasn’t comfortable, uh, with the options that I believe K___ was offering. I came initially for that reason. It’s strange that it was my dentist, so we talk about a lot. It’s strange how you get into certain things, uh, by having relationships with people who have gone through it. My dentist had, uh, numerous family members, had dealt with cancer, and he had recommended, he said, you know what, D___, this is what you need to do. You need to go to one of the teaching hospitals either here in DC you can go to J___ H___, in B___, and from my perspective, there are enough individuals that have come to J___ H___, that are close friends of mine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That said, they shared with me that, uh, if you have a choice, go to J___ H___. So when I came up, my thing was the consultation. We had the consultation. I left, and, uh, and I didn’t say anything. But there was a follow-up that was set for J___ H___. And we sat down, and we talked about this. So we have all these options here. We did the genetic testing. And I said, okay, this is an option just like anything else. If it does not work, it’s not like it’s the only option that we have. Doctor: Correct.

Family Member: Hi. Nice to see you. Doctor: So, you know, you done good. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: How about that? Family Member: Good news. No new treatments. Doctor: Yeah. I think you get a break for six weeks until I torture you with that, I mean help you, again. Family Member: What’s that going to involve? Patient: What’s going to happen in six weeks? Doctor: Nothing. I just want to make sure your PSA isn’t like skyrocketing. (Door sound) Patient: Oh. Doctor: You know? Ten, ten is okay. Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing?

Family Member: Alright. He said, oh, it’s, you know, it’s some weird- Doctor: Oh, my, oh, my, God. That is a scary thing to say and leave it hanging like that. Patient: I think he was trying to get rid of me. I don’t know. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. Yeah. That’s not something we would ignore or taken lightly, either. Patient: Okay. So then you’re going to give me an appointment for three months here? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. And um if anything changes on the scan, we’ll let you know. Patient: You’ll call me, and- Doctor: But you need your injection. Right? Today? Patient: Yes. Um hum. But in three months, I’ll get another CAT scan? Patient: Maybe not? Doctor: Yes.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Homemaker: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Homemaker

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
